fr:title.text: Yorkshire and Midlands Category Theory Seminar 32

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Yorkshire and Midlands Category Theory Seminar 32

fr:title.text: Jack Romo on homotopy bicategories of complete 2-fold Segal spaces

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Jack Romo on homotopy bicategories of complete 2-fold Segal spaces

fr:meta.name: venue

fr:link.title: Yorkshire and Midlands Category Theory Seminar 32

fr:meta.fr:link: Yorkshire and Midlands Category Theory Seminar 32

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Jack Romo gave a talk about homotopy bicategories of complete 2-fold Segal spaces. The goal of the work is to convert (∞,2)-categories to their (homotopy) bicategories; he has managed to define the homotopy bicategory, but I believe it is not yet functorial (part of the problem is to find the appropriate “category” for the domain of this “functor”).

The model of (∞,2)-category used is complete 2-fold Segal space, which is like an iteration of the Segal conditions. A complete Segal space is a simplicial diagram of (∞,1)-groupoids satisfying certain lifting conditions — the Segal condition says the projection of n-simplices to their “spines” should be a trivial fibration (contractible fibers!) A complete 2-fold Segal space is a simplicial diagram of complete Segal spaces satisfying similar conditions.

Computing the homotopy bicategory is non-trivial as various properties (existence of certainly lifts in the complete 2-fold Segal space) must be converted into structure (explicit associators, etc.). Jack is using an unbiased definition of bicategory due to Tom Leinster that is known to be equivalent to the bicategories of Jean Bénabou.

fr:meta.name: venue

fr:link.title: Yorkshire and Midlands Category Theory Seminar 32

fr:meta.fr:link: Yorkshire and Midlands Category Theory Seminar 32

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Kristina Sojakova described a huge advance on her prior work on syllepsis in homotopy type theory. In the prior work, there is a lot of path algebra to establish the syllepsis — to the point where going any further is practically impossible. Kristina has come up with a new way to prove Eckmann–Hilton, syllepsis, and higher syllepses that completely avoids this path algebra.

The idea is to generalize each statement to get rid of all the loops; in other words, a loop x : A, p: x = x is replaced by x : A, y : A, p : x = y as well as whatever other things are needed in order to generalize the statement involving loops. This doesn’t appear to be completely mechanical, but it is at least methodical. Once all the loops have been removed, the generalized statement is proved by applying path induction a ton of times, mindlessly. Then the original statement involving loops is easily seen to be an instance of the generalized one.
The new argument scales effortlessly from Eckmann–Hilton to syllepsis, to the “syllepsis of the syllepsis”.

This was easily the most interesting talk of YaMCATS32 for me; I am wondering if there are more painful things in HoTT that can be dealt with in this way. Jamie Vicary asked whether the proof is depending heavily on path induction having definitional computation rules; I think this is indeed the crux of the proof, although Benno van den Berg mentioned that it might still be possible to use this proof technique with the weak version of path induction. I think this is within the realm of “possibility” but I think it would be very painful.

fr:title.text: Stefania Damato on a container model of type theory

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Stefania Damato on a container model of type theory

fr:meta.name: venue

fr:link.title: Yorkshire and Midlands Category Theory Seminar 32

fr:meta.fr:link: Yorkshire and Midlands Category Theory Seminar 32

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Stefania Damato describes a model of type theory in (generalized) containers, joint work with her PhD supervisor Thorsten Altenkirch. The background of this work is the prior functorial semantics of QIITs due to Thorsten Altenkirch, Paolo Capriotti, Gabe Dijkstra, Nicolai Kraus, and Fredrik Nordvall Foresberg.

In that prior work, the universal property of QIITs is described in terms of certain functors having initial algebras, but the question of whether initial algebras in fact exist in usual semantic categories was not satisfactorily dealt with. In the context of ordinary inductive types, presentation by a container is a sufficient notion (i.e. the functor should be polynomial). In this work, Stefania Damato and Thorsten Altenkirch have needed to generalize the notion of polynomial in a way that Nicola Gambino suggested is equivalent to familial representability.

The motivation for finding a model of type theory in containers is that this is apparently necessary in order to be able to use type theoretic constructs in the signature of a QIIT. I never did fully understand how this relates to the constructs that appear in the constructors of the QIIT once its initial algebra is computed, as these happen in different models of type theory: the QIIT is specified, apparently, in the container model but then the QIIT is used in (e.g.) the \mathbf {Set} model. I chatted with Stefania Damato afterward and she offered some helpful answers, but I don’t think I fully understood this point.
